newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australis says report of concern wrong.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australis says report of concern wrong.

text.p: Pay television operator Australis Media Ltd said on Friday it believed that newspaper reports saying its largest U.S. bondholder was concerned about the recently announced rescue financing package were wrong.
"We believe that to be wrong," an Australis spokesman told Reuters.

The Sydney Morning Herald and The Australian Financial Review newspapers reported earlier on Friday that Merrill Lynch, Australis' largest U.S. bond-holder, was concerned about the cheap sale of Australis assets to rival operator Optus Vision as part of the US$105 million rescue package.
The Financial Review said The Seven Network Ltd, which has a two percent stake in Optus Vision, was also concerned the package gives too much of Optus to Kerry Packer.
The Australis spokesman said he could not comment immediately on this aspect of the reports or elaborate on the attitude of the U.S. bondholders to the deal.

Packer's Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd, Lenfest Communications Inc of the United States, Ron Brierley's Guinness Peat Group, UIH International Holdings and Television and Radio Services Pty Ltd agreed to inject a further US$105 million into Australis in conjunction with a joint venture agreement with Optus Vision.
The newspapers said Merrill Lynch was concerned that Australis had sold its assets to Optus Vision too cheaply.
"At this stage, however, it is unclear whether Merrill Lynch will withold its consent with talks between the parties set down for next week," The Sydney Morning Herald said.
Australis needs the approval of the bond holders to proceed with a further issue of US$225 million of bonds.
The US$105 million rescue package came after the bondholders demanded that at least US$100 million was injected before they granted approval.
Australis shares rose one cent to 26 cents on Thursday.
